en_first_half: No one had any idea what traveling through time might do to the human body. So the second reason that it was important to pick people who would have died in their own timelines is that they might well die in ours, like deep-sea
en_second_half: fish brought up to the beach. Perhaps there were only so many epochs the human nervous system could stand. If they got the temporal equivalent of the bends and sluiced into gray-and-pink jelly in a Ministry laboratory, at least it wouldn’t be, statistically speaking, murder.
en_Completion: fish brought up to the surface too quickly. The less the temporal displacement, the less the shock of the transfer. And the third reason was that if they were dead anyway, there was no possible way for them to interfere with the course of events that had already occurred. The consequences of meddling with the timeline were too dire to contemplate.

en_first_half: I liked my Languages job well enough, but I’d wanted to become a field agent, and after failing the field exams twice I was at a bit of a loss for career trajectory. en_second_half: I would “do something” about British foreign policy and I would also take my parents to fancy governmental dinners. I would have a chauffeur. (My mother never learned to drive; the chauffeur was important.) Regrettably she also drilled the karmic repercussions of gossip and lying into me—the fourth Buddhist precept is unambiguous on this—and thus at the age of eight my political career was over before it began.
en_Completion: she wanted me to be prime minister. en_first_half: This is everything I remember about my earliest hours with him. We separated and spent the fading day bobbing shyly around each other like clots in a lava lamp. I was expecting him to have a time-travel-induced psychotic break and perhaps chew or fold me with murderous intent. Mostly he touched things, with a compulsive brushing motion I was later to learn was because of permanent nerve damage from frostbite. He flushed the toilet fifteen times in a row, silent as
en_second_half: a kestrel while the cistern refilled, which could have been wonder or embarrassment. At hour two, we tried to sit in the same room. I looked up when he breathed in sharply through his nose to see him pulling his fingers away from a light bulb in the lamp. He retreated to his bedroom for a while, and I went to sit on the back porch. It was a mild spring evening. Idiot-eyed wood pigeons lumbered across the lawn, belly-deep in clover.
en_Completion: a ghost, and then stood in the shower for an hour, letting the water pour down on him like a benediction. I watched him from the doorway, mesmerized by the way the water seemed to wash away the years, revealing the young man he once was. He didn't seem to notice me, lost in his own thoughts, his eyes closed as if in prayer. I felt a pang of sadness, wondering what had brought him to this place, what had driven him

Nanantena azy aho fa hanana fotoana fialan-tsasatra ara-tsaina izy ary angamba mitsako na mampifanindry ahy amin'ny finiavana hamono olona. Ny ankamaroany dia nikasika zavatra izy, tamin'ny alalan'ny fihetsika tsy maintsy niborosy izay nianarako taty aoriana noho ny fahasimban'ny nerve maharitra avy amin'ny frostbite. Nitraka aho rehefa niaina mafy tamin'ny orony izy mba hahita azy misintona ny rantsan-tanany hiala amin'ny jiro iray. Nijanona tao amin'ny efitrano fatoriany izy nandritra ny fotoana kelikely, ary nipetraka teo amin'ny lavarangana aoriana aho. Alin'ny lohataona malefaka tamin'izay. en_second_half: like massaging wax from granite these days. The persistent grieving and shrieking of the wood of the ice-locked ship robs them of sleep and silence between paragraphs; without those fallow periods, all speech is feeble.
en_Completion: now a minefield. The wrong word, the wrong tone, and the whole room could go up in flames. They had all learned to tread carefully, to avoid the topics that could ignite the fuse. But the silence was oppressive, a heavy weight that hung in the air like a challenge. Someone had to break it, to take the risk and speak the words that would either bring them together or tear them apart.

en_first_half: He didn’t like twenty-first-century language. “Victorian” was his greatest descriptive enemy, and to be fair, I’d heard people apply the word miscellaneously to any period 1710–1916. But much of what I thought of as quintessentially “Victorian” was in his future and, to him, gargantuan, disproportionate, ungentlemanly, unpious. He didn’t understand my use of the term “classical music,” which
en_second_half: meant something to do with formal classicism to him and meant, to me, that it had violins. He hated “text” as a verb, “sex” as an act, “tomato” as a salad product. One afternoon he came in from a walk and asked me, very thoughtfully, “Some charming young women—out on the heath—addressed me quite boisterously—what is a ‘DILF’?”

en_first_half: While I was biting the skin off my thumb and rereading the “Undeliverable” notice, I got a phone call on my work phone from an unknown number. All phones assigned to the project
en_second_half: had private, protected numbers and there was no way it could have been a spam call, or even a casual one. I picked up. On the other end was the Vice Secretary for Expatriation.
en_Completion: had been set to reject calls from unknown numbers, but this one somehow got through. I hesitated for a moment, wondering if I should answer it, but my curiosity got the better of me. I picked up the phone and said, "Hello?" in a neutral tone. There was a pause on the other end, and then a low, gravelly voice spoke, "You're the one who's been trying to reach me, aren't you?"

en_first_half: Time happened to me very quickly, and then very slowly. Panic as much as grief warps the way internal
en_second_half: time works; I just had the wherewithal to wonder if this would be worth raising with the Wellness team.
en_Completion: clocks tick away, and the external world becomes a blur. In the aftermath of loss, time can feel like a twisted, unpredictable force, stretching out moments of agony and compressing hours of numbness into what feels like an instant. The world outside recedes, and all that's left is the aching void within, a chasm that seems impossible to bridge.

en_first_half: You can’t trauma-proof life, and you can’t hurt-proof your relationships. You have to accept you will cause harm to yourself and others. But you can also fuck up, really badly, and not learn anything from it except that you fucked up. It’s the same with oppression. You don’t gain any special knowledge from being marginalized. But you do gain something from stepping outside your hurt and examining the scaffolding
en_second_half: of your oppression. You’ll find the weak joints, the things you can kick in. When I look back at myself on the bridge year, I see that I thought I was doing something constructive, escaping exploitation by becoming exceptional. en_second_half: on the deeper darkness. We stumped our bikes over the wet, breathless earth.

en_first_half: The companies of Erebus and Terror struggle through the winter of 1847. Their best sportsman is dead—not that there’s much hunting to be had. A single storm on the ice wipes out another hunting party of two officers and three men, whose bodies are never found. Others succumb to the claws of the climate, to scurvy,
en_second_half: to madness. Men starve and rave, dreaming of gravy. There isn’t enough coal to heat the ships, nor enough candles to light the Arctic winter. Franklin’s bold adventurers lie for hours in the dark, too cold and hungry to move, while the darkness looks like ink-soaked cardboard pressed against the portholes. The ships smell like carrion.
en_Completion: to the claws of the climate, to scurvy, and to the slow, creeping grip of madness. The ships are trapped in the ice, unable to move, and the men are trapped in their own minds, unable to escape the crushing weight of their isolation. The days blend together in a never-ending blur of cold and darkness, and the men begin to lose all sense of time and reality. They are adrift in a sea of white, with no hope of rescue
mg_first_half: Ny orinasan'i Erebus sy ny Terror dia miady mandritra ny ririnina 1847. Maty ny mpanao fanatanjahantena tsara indrindra - tsy hoe betsaka ny zavatra tokony haza. mg_second_half: manonofy gravy. Tsy ampy ny arintany hanafanana ny sambo, na ny labozia ampy mba hanazava ny ririnina any amin'ny Tendrontany Avaratra.
